Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Evolution of Gene Expression in Floral Diversification of Neotropical Gesneriaceae.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Flowers are among the most common ways that people connect to nature and have enormous potential to engage broad audiences in science and evolution. In addition, an intriguing and complex question in biology is how genetic and ecological processes promoted the rapid evolution and diversification of flowers. This project focuses on a genus in the African violet family, which is comprised of many species with highly colorful and diverse flowers. Thus the researchers can use comparative genomic approaches to investigate how patterns of gene expression vary across multiple species and relate to flower traits important for speciation and pollination. Results of this work will aid researchers and government agencies interested in biodiversity and conservation by providing additional evidence for the complex genetic and ecological interactions between plants and pollinators that have promoted flower diversification.

High throughput sequencing of expressed genes from flowers in two developmental stages of 10 species of Achimenes will provide a powerful dataset for investigating evolutionary processes at the genome level. Specifically, the study will further our understanding of the role of gene expression and protein evolution in speciation. The researchers will use transcriptome-wide levels of gene expression across multiple species to associate variation in expression with evolutionary transitions between flower color, shape, and pollination syndrome. They will also determine if target genes expressed during flower development have signatures of positive selection. The genomic data generated will be used to (1) compare patterns of gene expression within and among species, (2) resolve phylogenetic relationships, and (3) identify shared and divergent changes to protein sequences that correlate to transitions in floral form and pollination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most intriguing evolutionary patterns is the diversity of flowers, especially when considering the important relationship between flowers and their pollinators. Understanding the genetic basis for floral diversity has important implications for both ecology and agriculture. For this project, we generated large floral transcriptome resources for 10 members of Achimenes, a genus of 26 taxa in the angiosperm family Gesneriaceae, which display numerous convergences in flower color, flower shape, and pollinator. We sequenced two developmental stages of the flower, which allows us to investigate temporal variation of gene expression both within and between taxa. Initially we used these resources to generate a well-resolved phylogenetic hypothesis of Achimenes, using over 1300 gene sequences. Our results indicate strong support for 2 distinct lineages, both improving and providing strong support for previously unidentified relationships. Incongruences in individual gene histories additionally led us to identify 3 possible instances of gene flow and hybridization between taxa that grow in sympatry and share pollinators. These analyses generated the necessary framework to understand patterns of floral convergence, particularly the number and direction of shifts between different pollinators.

            To investigate the genomic mechanisms of floral diversification, we employed a comparative transcriptomics approach. Gene expression was compared across all taxa, between taxa that shared the same pollinator (bees, butterflies, or hummingbirds), and within each taxon individually. Common sets of genes were found differentially expressed in all comparisons, including genes that are involved in flower color production. Gene expression data was also used to construct a coexpression network, where genes are connected to other genes that share a similar pattern of expression. This network of putative gene interactions allows us to test the hypothesis that distinct genetic modules underlie the parallel development of distinct floral forms associated with distinct pollinators. Most modules were strongly correlated to different flower colors, flower shapes, and pollinators. Modules associated with butterfly and hummingbird pollination had significantly higher evolutionary rates than other modules. Genes with higher evolutionary rates also had significantly lower levels of expression and higher connectivity to other genes, suggesting some level of evolutionary constraint.

            The results generated during the duration of this award have begun to shed light on the genetic and genomic patterns underlying floral form diversification in a non-model system. We show correlations between gene expression, network modularity, and floral form differences, but future functional work will be necessary to determine exactly how different genetic pathways contribute to flower diversification in Achimenes. This project provided the co-PI extensive research experience learning new lab techniques, analyzing large data sets, submitting manuscripts, and presenting at professional meetings. During this award, the co-PI worked with many local organizations to teach scientific inquiry and plant science to elementary school students.

            The results from this project may have direct broader impacts to the field of floral horticulture as well as plant conservation efforts. The breeding of desirable flower colors and shapes is of great importance and our results suggest and provide additional evidence that large phenotypic changes can result from changes in one or few genes. Deeper understanding of how plant-pollinator interactions have shaped plant diversity will also inform conservation efforts and how to mitigate the loss of many important animal and insect species that provide pollination in our agricultural systems.
